functional_requirements.high_level_requirement: Ability for the System to sync multiple concurrent edits by Users editing the same content
functional_requirements.detailed_requirement: nan
functional_requirements.comments:
Note:
Changes made to the same piece of content should be synced. The System should be able to detect conflicts between User updates and resolve the conflicts and allow the User to act upon them.

One example, the System to prompt User to resolve conflict by either consolidating the change/merge/overight/ignore and save/publish;)

Example:
-System should display all writers who are editing the page.
-User can lock document to prevent others from making simultaneous updates.
-Users can also unlock a document.

Example:
-Writer A needs to make an update to the document and beginning working on it.
- On another day, Writer B starts editing the same page that is currently editing.
- Writer A continues to make changes, at this point Writer B's updates are out of date and not synchronized. With the changes Writer A made.
- When Writer B saves, the System should check for conflicts between the versions from both Writers and display them to be resolved. (some options could be to merge, overright, manually resolve, publish without incorporating other users change, discard changes)

non_functional_requirements.high_level_requirement: Ability for the System to follow all guidelines pertaining to the Framework Agreement.
non_functional_requirements.notes:
Flagging cells yellow that contain what are functional requirements in a non-functional requirements set, and all cells purple that are contactual stipulations. Functional requirements should not be included in NFR sets, and contractual statements should not be written as requirements. Just because a function is technical in nature, doesn't mean it's NFR. This tab has not been reviewed or edited for content, format etc. Only highlighting these potential issues as a courtesy. All NFRs that reference external policy guidelines seem to be contractual. Referencing an external policy isn't really a functional requirement or a non-functional requirement. 

Definitions of FR and NFR FYI: 

Functional requirements describe the capabilities that a solution must have in terms of the behaviour and information that the solution will manage. They answer the question, âwhat does the solution need to do?â Functional requirements must not specify how the solution should be designed to perform these functions.

Non-Functional requirements do not relate directly to the behaviour or functionality of the solution, but rather describe conditions under which a solution must remain effective or qualities that a solution must have. The failure to identify non-functional requirements can result in a solution that is not fit for purpose because it takes too long, is too difficult to use or cannot operate under required conditions.

glossary.Administrative User:
Restricted access Users that are able to make changes to the System that will affect other Users or Clients.
There are many specializations of the Administrative User role based on the privileges required.
For example, Administrative Users may change security settings, install software and hardware, configure various components of the System, and make changes to other Users or Clients.
glossary.Analytics data: Captured raw information from System components that are processed and organized to create meaningful information.
glossary.Artificial intelligence (AI): Computer actions that mimic human decision making based on learned experiences and data
glossary.Audit trail: Chronological records of events and activities that have taken place within the System. Provides detailed history of User/System actions, interactions and changes to the System.
glossary.Boolean: A logical operator that is used to connect or modify the relationships between keywords or expressions in a search query.
glossary.Broadcast notification: Communication sent to multiple recipients within the System
glossary.Channel:
The medium in which Users/Client can interact with ESDC. It enables the User/Client experience and allows for flows of information, services and interactions between an organization and User/Clients through their journey.
Channel examples include digital, contact centre and in-person.
glossary.Chat logs: Text based record of written conversations exchanged between Users to User, or User to System.
glossary.Chat bot: System designed to simulate conversation with human users through text or voice input
glossary.CMS: Content Management System (CMS) provides an interface for Users to CRUD, Publish content without much in-depth technical knowledge. The CMS functions for content CRUDing, version control, workflow management and publishing capabilities.
glossary.Content: Refers to the various types of data and information that are created, stored and accessed within the System. Content can encompass text, images, audio, video, and other multimedia elements.
glossary.Contribution: Refers to the act of adding, enhancing, modifying the System.
glossary.CRUD: Create, Read, Update and Delete. This acronym covers related functions for view, edit, modify etc.
glossary.CSS: Cascading Style Sheets is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation and defines the visual formatting and appearance of a document written in HTML or XML
glossary.Dashboard: A display of data indicating an overview of key performance indicators. A collection of statistics measuring performance aggregated for viewing to identify insights.
glossary.Feedback: Process of providing input and comments on the System for the purposes of improvement
glossary.HTML: HyperText Markup Language is the standard language used for the creation and structuring of web pages and web applications.
glossary.Interoperability: The ability of different types of electronic devices, networks, operating systems, and applications to work together effectively, without prior communication, to exchange information in a useful and meaningful manner.
glossary.Live chat: Real-time communication that allows Users/Client to engage in text or voice based communication to ask and answer questions within the System
glossary.Machine Learning (ML): Processes that allow computers to derive conclusions from data. ML is a subset of AI that enables the ability for computers to learn outside of their programming
glossary.Metadata: Descriptive information about data, resources, or content within the System that provides details about context, characteristics, structure of the primary data it is describing.
glossary.Natural Language Processing (NLP): Branch of Artificial intelligence and computational linguistics focused on enabling computers to understand and interpret context and generate human language.
glossary.Notification: Message or alert that is delivered to users to inform them about updates or activities within the System.
glossary.Official Languages: A language defined under the Official Languages Act as an official language of Canada, namely English or French.
glossary.Omnichannel: The capacity for service offerings to be delivered through in-person, phone and e-service channels
glossary.Operand: The data or value that is operated on by an operator within an expression.
glossary.Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): RAG is the process of optimizing the output of a LLM, so it references an authoritative knowledge base outside of its training data sources before generating a response. RAG extends the capability of LLMs to specific domains or an organizationâs internal knowledge base.
glossary.Role-based Access Control (RBAC): Provides a method of restricting access based on a Users' role within the System
glossary.Reusable content: Reusable asset that is designed and structured for reuse across the System
glossary.System: System refers to the Knowledge Management Solution or any other solution used at ESDC.
glossary.User: A User is an employee of ESDC that interfaces with the Knowledge Management solution.
glossary.User Groups: Logical grouping of Users that share certain permissions within the System for the purposes of access control
glossary.User Profile: Set of information about the user, preferences, skill tags. The User profile determines what the User can view within the System
glossary.Role: Predefined set of permissions and access rights that are assigned to individuals based on their responsibilities and function within ESDC
glossary.web traffic: Interactions between the User and the System
glossary.Wildcard: Character or sequence of characters that serves as a placeholder to represent one or more other characters
glossary.Workflow: Refers to the series of activities, tasks and operations within the System
glossary.WYSIWYG: Stands for "What you see is what you get" and refers to the interfaces and editors that allow Users to directly manipulate the content in a manner that closely resembles the final output
